elements.content: Novel uranyl coordination polymers, UO2(bqdc)­(phen)·H2O (1), [UO2(μ-OH)­(bqdc)­(H2bpy)0.5(H2O)] (2), Na­[(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na­(H2O)2] (3), and [Na­(bqdc)0.5(bpp)­(H2O)] (4) (H2bqdc = 2,2′-biquinoline-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine; bpp = 1,3-di­(4-pyridyl)­propane), with bqdc2– ligands have been successfully synthesized by hydrothermal reactions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, Infrared spectroscopy (IR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The topological structures feature 1D chain to 3D framework by altering N-donor ancillary ligands. Compound 1 shows a 1D wave-shaped zigzag chain structure and further extends to a two-dimensional (2D) layer through π···π interactions between the quinoline ring of bqdc2– ligand and benzene ring of phen ligand. The uranium adopts an approximate hexagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry with the equatorial plane warped to the unusual chair conformation. Compound 2 features rectangular-shaped units with space range of 12.28(2) Å × 7.16(3) Å, exhibiting an intriguing 2D uranyl double layered motif formed by 1D ladder chains. The protonated bpy molecules provide space filling and form hydrogen bonds with the layers. Compound 3 is based upon 3D heterometallic frameworks constructed from UO2 2+, Na+, and bqdc2– ligands. The most striking feature of compound 3 is that one sodium ion is located in the middle of two adjacent uranyl ions, forming the trinuclear heterometal clusters (U2Na), which are further connected by bqdc2– ligands to generate UOFs with the cavity size of 10.07(0) Å × 13.86(2) Å. The local 1D structure of compound 3 is similar to the zigzag chain of compound 1. Compound 4 displays 1D chain structure and further extends to 3D framework via hydrogen bond and π···π interactions. Moreover, the electronic structural and bonding properties of the uranyl compounds 1–3 have been systematically explored by density functional theory (DFT) calculations.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, the crystal engineering of coordination polymers (CPs) has received much attention, not only because of their versatile intriguing architectures of these compounds but also owing to their potential applications in ion exchange, catalysis, gas storage and separation, biomaterials, magnetic, nonlinear optics, and luminescence sensors. However, compared with the splendid works based on transition and lanthanide metals, the coordination chemistry of actinides still remains less developed. Uranium, one of the most investigated actinide elements, exhibits rich coordination chemistry, fascinating structural diversities, excellent physicochemical properties, and even the potential value in the nuclear fuel cycle. The linear uranyl (UO2 2+) species, as the existing form of hexavalent uranium, in the most cases, are “off-limits” to further coordination at the axial positions. As a consequence, it only permits coordination to donors close to the equatorial plane. The inherent chemical feature would then favor the formation of low-dimensional networks, and the three-dimensional (3D) uranyl compounds are rare. Further, the uranyl cation often oligomerizes via uranyl hydrolysis and forms polynuclear building units, which can increase the topological diversity of uranyl CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few decades, the crystal engineering of coordination polymers (CPs) has received much attention, not only because of their versatile intriguing architectures of these compounds but also owing to their potential applications in ion exchange, catalysis, gas storage and separation, biomaterials, magnetic, nonlinear optics, and luminescence sensors. However, compared with the splendid works based on transition and lanthanide metals, the coordination chemistry of actinides still remains less developed. Uranium, one of the most investigated actinide elements, exhibits rich coordination chemistry, fascinating structural diversities, excellent physicochemical properties, and even the potential value in the nuclear fuel cycle. The linear uranyl (UO2 2+) species, as the existing form of hexavalent uranium, in the most cases, are "off-limits" to further coordination at the axial positions. As a consequence, it only permits coordination to donors close to the equatorial plane. The inherent chemical feature would then favor the formation of low-dimensional networks, and the three-dimensional (3D) uranyl compounds are rare. Further, the uranyl cation often oligomerizes via uranyl hydrolysis and forms polynuclear building units, which can increase the topological diversity of uranyl CPs.

elements.content: One of the most common strategies employed in constructing uranyl CPs is to associate uranyl centers with suitable ligands. For example, 2,2′-biquinoline-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2bqdc) is a typical example of polycarboxylate derivatives containing pyridine linker for the construction of novel CPs. It was widely used to synthesize alkali, transition, and lanthanide metal compounds, but none has been reported about actinide ions. In addition, the architecture of uranyl CPs can be further modified by introducing organic bases (such as 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), and 1,3-di­(4-pyridyl)­propane (bpp)), which act as auxiliary ligands or templating agents, to the reaction system.
elements.clean_text: One of the most common strategies employed in constructing uranyl CPs is to associate uranyl centers with suitable ligands. For example, 2,2'-biquinoline-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bqdc) is a typical example of polycarboxylate derivatives containing pyridine linker for the construction of novel CPs. It was widely used to synthesize alkali, transition, and lanthanide metal compounds, but none has been reported about actinide ions. In addition, the architecture of uranyl CPs can be further modified by introducing organic bases (such as 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp)), which act as auxiliary ligands or templating agents, to the reaction system.

elements.content: Inspired by the aforementioned considerations, we are interested in exploring various uranyl CPs that can be formed in the mixed ligands system containing H2bqdc molecules and neutral N-donor ligands. Herein, we report the first uranyl compound with H2bqdc as the main linker and phen, bpy, and bpp as the auxiliary ligands (), namely, UO2(bqdc)­(phen)·H2O (1), UO2(μ-OH)­(bqdc)­(H2bpy)0.5(H2O) (2), and Na­[(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na­(H2O)2] (3), which show a systematic variation of architectures from one-dimensional (1D) chains to 3D UOFs. Besides, mononuclear Na­(I) compound Na­(bqdc)0.5(bpp)­(H2O) (4) was found as the minor phase accompanied by the formation of compound 3.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the aforementioned considerations, we are interested in exploring various uranyl CPs that can be formed in the mixed ligands system containing H2bqdc molecules and neutral N-donor ligands. Herein, we report the first uranyl compound with H2bqdc as the main linker and phen, bpy, and bpp as the auxiliary ligands (), namely, UO2(bqdc)(phen)⋅H2O (1), UO2(μ-OH)(bqdc)(H2bpy)0.5(H2O) (2), and Na[(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na(H2O)2] (3), which show a systematic variation of architectures from one-dimensional (1D) chains to 3D UOFs. Besides, mononuclear Na(I) compound Na(bqdc)0.5(bpp)(H2O) (4) was found as the minor phase accompanied by the formation of compound 3.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Caution! The uranyl nitrate hexahydrate UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O is a radioactive and chemically toxic reactant; precautions with suitable care and protection for handling such substances should be followed although it was used in the experiment.

elements.content: A series of uranyl CPs have been hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves. The following reactants were used in the synthesis: uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%), 2,2′-biquinoline-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid (H2bqdc, Aladdin, 98%), 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy, Aladdin, 98%), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen, Aladdin, 98%), 1,3-di­(4-pyridyl)­propane (bpp, Acros, 98%), and ultrapure water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ·cm–1). All starting reagents in these syntheses are commercially available and used without any further purification.
elements.clean_text: A series of uranyl CPs have been hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves. The following reactants were used in the synthesis: uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, 99%), 2,2'-biquinoline-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bqdc, Aladdin, 98%), 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy, Aladdin, 98%), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen, Aladdin, 98%), 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp, Acros, 98%), and ultrapure water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm-1). All starting reagents in these syntheses are commercially available and used without any further purification.

elements.content: The fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and solid sample holder. The photomultiplier tube voltage was 700 V, the excitation and the emission slit width were 5.0 and 5.0 nm, respectively, and the scan speed was 60 nm/min. IR measurement was obtained on a Bruker Tensor 27 infrared spectrometer. Sample was diluted with spectroscopic KBr and pressed into a pellet. The measured wavenumber is between 400 and 4000 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Bruker, D8-Advance X-ray Diffractometer) was performed with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, TA Instruments, Q500) was employed in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C·min–1.

elements.content: UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2bqdc (51.64 mg, 0.15 mmol), phen (28.03 mg, 0.15 mmol), NaOH (4.08 mg, 0.1 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, then cooled to room temperature naturally. Yellow crystals of compound 1 were produced, then filtered off, washed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air-drying at room temperature. Yield: 41.6 mg (51.3% based on uranium). In the absence of the auxiliary ligands (phen), only the brown block noncrystalline materials were observed.

The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, then cooled to room temperature naturally. Dark yellow crystals of compound 3 were produced, then filtered off, washed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air-drying at room temperature. Yield: 34.5 mg (40.9% based on uranium). Here, the auxiliary ligand was not incorporated into the structure of compound 3. Surprisingly, few light yellow block-shaped crystals of compound 4 were observed in one pot.

Na[(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na(H2O)2] (3) and Na(bqdc)0.5(bpp)(H2O) (4)

Dark yellow crystals of compound 3 were produced, then filtered off, washed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air-drying at room temperature. Yield: 34.5 mg (40.9% based on uranium). Here, the auxiliary ligand was not incorporated into the structure of compound 3. Surprisingly, few light yellow block-shaped crystals of compound 4 were observed in one pot.

elements.content: The intensity data of compound 1 was collected on a Bruker APEXII X-ray diffractometer equipped with a CMOS PHOTON 100 detector with a Mo Kα X-ray source (Kα = 0.71073 Å). The X-ray diffraction data of compounds 2–4 was performed with synchrotron radiation facility at BSRF (beamline 3W1A of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility, λ = 0.71000 Å) using a MAR CCD detector. Data were indexed, integrated and scaled using DENZO and SCALEPACK from the HKL program suite (Otwinowski and Minor, 1997). All of the crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Due to the weak crystal diffraction of compounds 2 and 3, some solvent molecules and counter cations experience serious disorder. Therefore, the SQUEEZE function of PLATON was applied. Pertinent crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

The intensity data of compound 1 was collected on a Bruker APEXII X-ray diffractometer equipped with a CMOS PHOTON 100 detector with a Mo Kα X-ray source (Kα = 0.71073 Å). The X-ray diffraction data of compounds 2-4 was performed with synchrotron radiation facility at BSRF (beamline 3W1A of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility, λ = 0.71000 Å) using a MAR CCD detector. Data were indexed, integrated and scaled using DENZO and SCALEPACK from the HKL program suite (Otwinowski and Minor, 1997). All of the crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Due to the weak crystal diffraction of compounds 2 and 3, some solvent molecules and counter cations experience serious disorder. Therefore, the SQUEEZE function of PLATON was applied. Pertinent crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in .

All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the B3LYP hybrid functional by using the Gaussian 09 program package. For the uranium atom, the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECPs) with 60 core electrons were considered, and the ECP60MWB_SEG basis sets were adopted for describing the remaining electrons. For the H, C, N, and O atoms, the 6-31G­(d) basis sets were used. The initial structures for the model fragments of the uranyl compounds 1–3 were obtained from the X-ray crystal structures. All the molecular geometries were optimized in aqueous solution without any symmetry constraints, and in each structure, the coordinates of oxygen atoms far away from the uranium centers were fixed during optimization. Solvent effects were taken into account by using conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) and Klamt radii. At the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G­(d) level of theory, harmonic vibrational frequencies were calculated to confirm the local minima character of the structures. To further understand the electronic properties of the uranyl compounds, natural population analysis (NPA), Mayer bond order (MBO), and molecular orbital (MO) analyses were performed at the same level of theory. The quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis was carried out based on the optimized geometrical structures using Multiwfn 3.3.8 package.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Methods

All the density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed with the B3LYP hybrid functional by using the Gaussian 09 program package. For the uranium atom, the quasi-relativistic effective core potentials (RECPs) with 60 core electrons were considered, and the ECP60MWB_SEG basis sets were adopted for describing the remaining electrons. For the H, C, N, and O atoms, the 6-31G(d) basis sets were used. The initial structures for the model fragments of the uranyl compounds 1-3 were obtained from the X-ray crystal structures. All the molecular geometries were optimized in aqueous solution without any symmetry constraints, and in each structure, the coordinates of oxygen atoms far away from the uranium centers were fixed during optimization. Solvent effects were taken into account by using conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) and Klamt radii. At the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G(d) level of theory, harmonic vibrational frequencies were calculated to confirm the local minima character of the structures. To further understand the electronic properties of the uranyl compounds, natural population analysis (NPA), Mayer bond order (MBO), and molecular orbital (MO) analyses were performed at the same level of theory. The quantum theory of atoms in molecules (QTAIM) analysis was carried out based on the optimized geometrical structures using Multiwfn 3.3.8 package.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a triclinic form with space group of P1̅ (). The asymmetric unit contains one uranyl ion, one bqdc2– ligand, and one N-containing auxiliary ligand (phen), as illustrated in a. The U1 ion has a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal coordination environment with four oxygen atoms from two bqdc2– ligands (the U–O bond distances range from 2.436(2) to 2.492(2) Å), two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand (the U–N distances are 2.600(3) and 2.687(3) Å) in the equatorial plane, and two “yl” oxygens (the O1UO2 angle is 179.03(11)°, and the UO distances are 1.753(2) and 1.762(3) Å) at the axial positions (a). All these angles and bond distances are in good agreement with those in the literature. The uranyl-centered monomeric motifs are connected to each other through the carboxylate arms of the bqdc2– ligands to generate an infinite uranyl one-dimensional (1D) wave-shaped zigzag chain (a,b), further connected with each other via face-to-face π···π interaction between the quinoline ring of bqdc2– ligand and benzene ring of phen ligand to form a 2D layered structure, with an intercentroid distance of 3.64(4) Å, which is in agreement with typical π-stacking distances of 3.3–3.8 Å for metal–aromatic compounds (c).

Results and Discussion

Structural Description

UO2(bqdc)(phen) (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a triclinic form with space group of P1̅ (). The asymmetric unit contains one uranyl ion, one bqdc2- ligand, and one N-containing auxiliary ligand (phen), as illustrated in a. The U1 ion has a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal coordination environment with four oxygen atoms from two bqdc2- ligands (the U-O bond distances range from 2.436(2) to 2.492(2) Å), two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand (the U-N distances are 2.600(3) and 2.687(3) Å) in the equatorial plane, and two "yl" oxygens (the O1UO2 angle is 179.03(11)°, and the UO distances are 1.753(2) and 1.762(3) Å) at the axial positions (a). All these angles and bond distances are in good agreement with those in the literature. The uranyl-centered monomeric motifs are connected to each other through the carboxylate arms of the bqdc2- ligands to generate an infinite uranyl one-dimensional (1D) wave-shaped zigzag chain (a,b), further connected with each other via face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the quinoline ring of bqdc2- ligand and benzene ring of phen ligand to form a 2D layered structure, with an intercentroid distance of 3.64(4) Å, which is in agreement with typical π-stacking distances of 3.3-3.8 Å for metal-aromatic compounds (c).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ (). The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one crystallographically independent UO2 2+, one bqdc2– anion, one μ-OH, one coordinated water molecule, and half uncoordinated H2bpy2+ molecule, as depicted in b. The U1 is 7-fold coordinated with two uranyl oxygen atoms [1.781(8) Å for U1O7, 1.785(9) for U1 = O8, and 178.1(3)° for O7U1O8] at the apical positions, two hydroxyl groups [2.332(7) Å for U1–O6 and 2.355(6) Å for U1–O6′], two carboxyl oxygen atoms [2.403(7) Å for U1–O1 and 2.459(9) Å for U1–O4], and one water molecule [2.479(1) Å for U1–O5W] in the equatorial plane. The U1-centered pentagonal bipyramid is linked to the neighboring U1-centered pentagonal bipyramid via a common edge-sharing connection mode with two hydroxyl groups, generating a dinuclear motif [the U1···U1 distance is 3.87(1) Å]. Furthermore, adjacent dimeric units connect with each other by two bqdc2– ligands, resulting in a 1D ladder-like polymeric chain (a). Interestingly, the 1D ladder features rectangular-shaped units (named A) with a space range of 12.28(2) Å × 7.16(3) Å, as shown in b.

elements.content: The X-ray crystal structure analysis provided the formula [(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na­(H2O)2]− of compound 3, and the remaining charge is presumably balanced by Na+ cation located in the structure. ICP-OES and EDS analyses indicate the ratio of Na+/UO2 2+ ≈ 1:1 per formula unit (Figure S1). Half equivalent Na+ cations were not assigned in the crystal structure presumably because of its weak X-ray scattering. The result of X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 3 crystallizes in a monoclinic C2/c space group () as a 3D uranyl coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit of [(UO2)2(bqdc)3Na­(H2O)2]− in compound 3 consists of one crystallographically independent UO2 2+ atom, a half Na+ atom, one and a half bqdc2– ligands, and one disordered coordinated water molecule, which splits into O5 and O6, as shown in c. The U1 is 8-fold coordinated with two uranyl oxygen atoms [1.765(9) Å for U1O7, 1.754(9) for U1O8, and 179.6(4)° for O7U1O8] at the apical positions and six other oxygen atoms [the U–O bond length ranges from 2.371(10) to 2.503(8) Å] located in the equatorial hexagonal plane, comparable to those in the literature. Meanwhile, the Na1 polyhedron contains six O atoms from two H2O molecules and four different bqdc2– ligands, thus generating a six-coordination environment with an octahedral geometry (a).

elements.content: Remarkably, the Na1 polyhedron associates with two adjacent uranium hexagonal bipyramidals via corner-sharing oxygen atoms (O1 and O4) to form the trinuclear heterometal clusters (U2Na), as shown in b, which are linked by bqdc2– ligands, and then the complicated 3D framework structure was generated with cavity size of 10.07(0) Å × 13.86(2) Å (c,d). To afford a better insight of the structure, considering the trinuclear heterometal clusters as six-connected nodes and the bqdc2– ligands as linkers, the framework of compound 3 can be rationalized as a 3D pcu net (e).

elements.content: Herein, we describe the 3D structure of compound 3 in detail to identify the interactions between the ligands and metals. As shown in a, the uranyl ions are linked together by the bqdc2– ligands to form a zigzag chain, which is similar to the 1D structure of compound 1 (b). Notably, in compound 1, the coordination environment of the uranium is quite distorted in the equatorial plane due to the steric hindrance caused by the phen ligand. The bqdc2– ligand prefers good coplanarity, and two neighboring ones lie in the cis-position of the uranyl with a dihedral angle of 38.804° (a), which leads to the zigzag chain of compound 1 transforming into the wave-shaped structure. However, in the zigzag chain of compound 3, the adjacent bqdc2– ligands are almost coplanar due to the quite small dihedral angle of 2.350° (b), and the approximately planar chains are interconnected by bqdc2– ligands to build the 2D structure (c). The most interesting structural feature is that the linker bqdc2– ligands are upright compared to the 1D chains, resulting in the rare stair-shaped 2D layer (d). The adjacent 2D layers connect with each other via the Na+ cations filling between layers (e) to form the extended 3D UOF structure. Therefore, the Na+ cations play important roles in the formation of compound 3. Half equivalents of these alkali metal ions act as bridges linking the 2D layers to a 3D structure, and the rest of the ions fill the holes to balance the negative charges of the framework.

elements.content: To evaluate the computational methods and cluster models we used in this work, the geometrical structures for the model fragments of compounds 1, 2, and 3 were first optimized in aqueous solution at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G­(d) level of theory. As shown in , the optimized geometries are found to be in accordance with the X-ray crystal structures. Compound 1 has two bidentate bqdc2– ligands and one bidentate phen ligand, resulting in a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal structure. Similar conformation has been found for compound 3 with three bidentate bqdc2– ligands. Compound 2 is a binuclear hydroxyl-bridged species with two monodentate bqdc2– ligands as well as one water molecule in each uranyl cation, forming a 5-fold coordinated compound in the uranyl equatorial plane. In addition, compared with the experimental geometrical parameters (Tables S1–S3), the calculated U–O and U–N bond distances are predicted to be in good agreement with the experimental results with the differences within 0.1 Å. These results indicate that the present theoretical method we used here can predict reasonable results for the uranyl compounds. According to the calculated and experimental results, the U–N bond distances of the phen ligand in compound 1 are longer than the U–O bonds of the bqdc2– ligands, suggesting the weaker coordinating ability of the phen ligand. In compound 2, the U–U distance is about 3.9 Å, which is much longer than the sum of the predicted U single-bond covalent radius (3.4 Å). Thus, there is probably no direct uranium–uranium interaction for this compound. Most of the U–O­(OH–) (U1–O6, U1–O6′, U1′–O6, and U1′–O6′) bonds have relatively shorter bond distances, while the U–O­(H2O) (U1–O5w and U1′–O5w′) bond distances are longer than other bonds in compound 2.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Results of Compounds 1-3 

To evaluate the computational methods and cluster models we used in this work, the geometrical structures for the model fragments of compounds 1, 2, and 3 were first optimized in aqueous solution at the B3LYP/RECP/6-31G(d) level of theory. As shown in , the optimized geometries are found to be in accordance with the X-ray crystal structures. Compound 1 has two bidentate bqdc2- ligands and one bidentate phen ligand, resulting in a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal structure. Similar conformation has been found for compound 3 with three bidentate bqdc2- ligands. Compound 2 is a binuclear hydroxyl-bridged species with two monodentate bqdc2- ligands as well as one water molecule in each uranyl cation, forming a 5-fold coordinated compound in the uranyl equatorial plane. In addition, compared with the experimental geometrical parameters (Tables S1-S3), the calculated U-O and U-N bond distances are predicted to be in good agreement with the experimental results with the differences within 0.1 Å. These results indicate that the present theoretical method we used here can predict reasonable results for the uranyl compounds. According to the calculated and experimental results, the U-N bond distances of the phen ligand in compound 1 are longer than the U-O bonds of the bqdc2- ligands, suggesting the weaker coordinating ability of the phen ligand. In compound 2, the U-U distance is about 3.9 Å, which is much longer than the sum of the predicted U single-bond covalent radius (3.4 Å). Thus, there is probably no direct uranium-uranium interaction for this compound. Most of the U-O(OH-) (U1-O6, U1-O6', U1'-O6, and U1'-O6') bonds have relatively shorter bond distances, while the U-O(H2O) (U1-O5w and U1'-O5w') bond distances are longer than other bonds in compound 2.

elements.content: On the basis of the optimized geometrical structures, electronic properties of the uranyl compounds have been analyzed by NPA, MBO, QTAIM, and MO at the same level of theory. According to NPA analysis, the natural charges on the uranium atoms in compounds 1–3 are about 1.4, which are smaller than that in the free uranyl cations (2.9). This indicates stronger charge transfers from the ligands to the uranyl centers. Additionally, compound 3 shows slightly smaller metallic net charge (1.405) than compounds 1 (1.449) and 2 (1.457), indicating higher ligand-to-metal donation for the former. Thus, compare with the 6-fold-coordinated compounds 1 and 3, the bidentate bqdc2– ligand seems to have stronger ligand-to-metal donation ability than the phen ligand. This can be also confirmed by the shorter U–O bond distances in compound 3. For compounds 1–3, the MBOs of the UO bonds are about 2.1 (Tables S1–S3), indicating that these bonds have double-bond characters. Besides, the larger electron density (ρ) values (>0.20 a.u.) at the UO bond critical points (BCPs) also suggest significant covalent character of the UO bonding. As for all the U–O and U–N bonds in the equatorial plane, the small MBOs and ρ values indicate weak covalency of these bonds. As expected, the predicted MBOs and ρ values of the U–O bonds in compound 1 are larger than those of the U–N bonds. For compound 2, the U–U MBO is predicted to be 0.035. At the same time, no BCP has been observed between the two uranium centers. These results further confirm the absence of a direct uranium–uranium bond. Besides, the relatively larger MBOs and ρ values for the bonds between the uranium and the hydroxyl groups (U1–O6, U1–O6′, U1′–O6, and U1′–O6′ bonds) clearly indicate that the bridging hydroxyl groups have a profound effect on the stability of the binuclear uranyl compound. – show the lowest unoccupied MO (LUMO), the highest occupied MO (HOMO) orbitals, and the main MOs referring to the U–O and U–N bonding for the model fragments of compounds 1–3. For compounds 1 and 3, the LUMO (a and a) and HOMO (b and b) orbitals are mainly composed of contributions from the bqdc2– ligands. The metal–ligand σ-bonding orbitals (c,d and c–e) are found in the relatively low-energy areas, and these orbitals mainly attribute to U 5f, 6d, 7s and O, N 2p orbital interactions (Table S4). Interestingly, the LUMO (a) orbital for compound 2 corresponds to the 5f orbital of uranium, while the bqdc2– ligand mainly contributes to the HOMO (b) orbital. Significant U–O­(OH–) and U–O­(bqdc2–) σ-bonding orbitals (c–e) have been observed in the low-energy area. Besides, there is no U–U bonding interaction having been found in the MOs of compound 2. All these results are in line with the bond distance analysis.

elements.content: As described above, three uranyl coordination polymers with different auxiliary ligands were successfully synthesized. These auxiliary ligands play critical but different roles in the formation of the compounds because the absence of them in the reaction systems could not yield any crystal. In compound 1, the phen ligand coordinates to the uranyl cation via two N atoms with U–N bond distances of 2.600(3) and 2.687(3) Å, which are longer than the U–O bonds of the bqdc2– ligands. Meanwhile, the steric effect of phen ligands leads to the deviation of the six coordination atoms (N1, N2, O3, O4, O5, and O6) from the equatorial plane (a), leading to the twisted arrangement of bqdc2– ligands and evolution to a wave-shaped chain structure. Uranyl compounds in which most equatorial plane atoms diverge from planarity seriously (by more than 0.2 Å) are quite rare, mostly seen in hexacoordinated uranyl compounds with large space steric hindrance ligand, such as phenanthroline. Most of these uranyl compounds adopt a 1,2- or 1,4-position coordination mode around the equatorial area, in which only two atoms occupying 1,2- or 1,4-positions are close to the equatorial plane, while the other four atoms are away from the plane (Figures S6a and S6b). However, as shown in b, the 1,3 positions atoms, O4 and O6, are next to the equatorial plane in compound 1. This unusual 1,3-position mode forces the coordination hexagonal flat to warp to chair-type structure (Figure S6c). In compound 2, the bpy ligands act as linkers to facilitate the construction of the 2D stacking structure through hydrogen bonding. In addition, the protonated H2bpy2+ cations balance the negative charges of the 2D framework. At the same time, the organic bases act as guest molecules to fill in the void space of the UOF and enhance the stability of framework. Although bpp is not incorporated in the crystal structure, it is indispensable for the formation of compound 3 because of its role as a template agent. Comparing the packing structures of compounds 1–3, with altering of auxiliary ligands, the dimensionality of three compounds increases: from 1D chain to 3D framework. As a strong bidentate ligand, phen trends to occupy two coordination positions in the equatorial plane of the uranyl cation. Because of the large steric effect, phen may reduce the coordination space of the carboxylate ligand, resulting in the low-dimensional compounds. Bpy is a common auxiliary ligand for constructing uranyl compounds. However, the bpy ligand does not connect with the uranium atom directly in most of these compounds because of its lower affinity to uranium center than the carboxylate ligand, even the water molecule. It usually acts as the guest molecule, charge balancing molecule or hydrogen bonding, and π···π interaction participant, which stabilizes the structure of the compounds. The number of actinide compounds with bpp ligand is quite limited, which may originate from the weak coordinating ability and flexibility structure. In summary, although the auxiliary ligands play different roles in the reaction systems, what they have in common is that they all contribute to the crystallization of compounds. It is of course meaningful for further attempts to synthesize novel uranyl coordination polymers.

Ligand Conformation and the Role of the Auxiliary Ligands

As described above, three uranyl coordination polymers with different auxiliary ligands were successfully synthesized. These auxiliary ligands play critical but different roles in the formation of the compounds because the absence of them in the reaction systems could not yield any crystal. In compound 1, the phen ligand coordinates to the uranyl cation via two N atoms with U-N bond distances of 2.600(3) and 2.687(3) Å, which are longer than the U-O bonds of the bqdc2- ligands. Meanwhile, the steric effect of phen ligands leads to the deviation of the six coordination atoms (N1, N2, O3, O4, O5, and O6) from the equatorial plane (a), leading to the twisted arrangement of bqdc2- ligands and evolution to a wave-shaped chain structure. Uranyl compounds in which most equatorial plane atoms diverge from planarity seriously (by more than 0.2 Å) are quite rare, mostly seen in hexacoordinated uranyl compounds with large space steric hindrance ligand, such as phenanthroline. Most of these uranyl compounds adopt a 1,2- or 1,4-position coordination mode around the equatorial area, in which only two atoms occupying 1,2- or 1,4-positions are close to the equatorial plane, while the other four atoms are away from the plane (Figures S6a and S6b). However, as shown in b, the 1,3 positions atoms, O4 and O6, are next to the equatorial plane in compound 1. This unusual 1,3-position mode forces the coordination hexagonal flat to warp to chair-type structure (Figure S6c). In compound 2, the bpy ligands act as linkers to facilitate the construction of the 2D stacking structure through hydrogen bonding. In addition, the protonated H2bpy2+ cations balance the negative charges of the 2D framework. At the same time, the organic bases act as guest molecules to fill in the void space of the UOF and enhance the stability of framework. Although bpp is not incorporated in the crystal structure, it is indispensable for the formation of compound 3 because of its role as a template agent. Comparing the packing structures of compounds 1-3, with altering of auxiliary ligands, the dimensionality of three compounds increases: from 1D chain to 3D framework. As a strong bidentate ligand, phen trends to occupy two coordination positions in the equatorial plane of the uranyl cation. Because of the large steric effect, phen may reduce the coordination space of the carboxylate ligand, resulting in the low-dimensional compounds. Bpy is a common auxiliary ligand for constructing uranyl compounds. However, the bpy ligand does not connect with the uranium atom directly in most of these compounds because of its lower affinity to uranium center than the carboxylate ligand, even the water molecule. It usually acts as the guest molecule, charge balancing molecule or hydrogen bonding, and π⋅⋅⋅π interaction participant, which stabilizes the structure of the compounds. The number of actinide compounds with bpp ligand is quite limited, which may originate from the weak coordinating ability and flexibility structure. In summary, although the auxiliary ligands play different roles in the reaction systems, what they have in common is that they all contribute to the crystallization of compounds. It is of course meaningful for further attempts to synthesize novel uranyl coordination polymers.

elements.content: As shown in Scheme S1, the bqdc2– ligand adopts different coordination modes in compounds 1–3. In compounds 1 and 2, the bqdc2– ligand acts as a μ2-bridge to link two uranyl cations with bidentate mode and monodentate mode, respectively. However, in compound 3, the whole bqdc2– ligand functions as a μ4-bridge connecting two uranyl cations and two Na+ ions. Although the C–C bond between two quinolone rings can rotate freely, the bqdc2– ligand adopts almost the same steric configuration in compounds 1–3. The two quinolone rings are almost coplanar and two carboxyl groups are just in the relative farthest positions. It may be the most stable space configuration because of the lowest steric effect. However, the bqdc2– ligand or its esterified derivative adopts another steric configuration when coordinating with transition metal ions. One quinolone ring of the ligand rotates 180°, and two nitrogen atoms come to one side to chelate a transition metal ion (). It is predictable that if transition metal ions are introduced to the reaction system of compounds 1–3, novel heterometallic compounds in which the bqdc2– ligand adopts new steric configuration and coordination mode will be synthesized. Intensive study is in progress in our laboratory.

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 3 were characterized by IR spectroscopy (Figure S2), and their IR spectra are similar. Hence, we only identify the IR spectroscopy of compound 1 in detail. The broad peak appearing near 3440 cm–1 is due to the stretching vibration of O–H bond in dissociative water. The aromatic ring C–H stretching vibration absorptions and out of plane bending absorptions are observed in the range of 2800 to 3100 cm–1 and 665 to 750 cm–1, respectively. Another characteristic absorption spectroscopy of the aromatic ring is the skeletal vibrations that can be observed near 1591, 1530, and 1430 cm–1. For the carboxylate groups, the most important absorption peaks are attributed to CO and C–O stretching vibration absorption, and the former appears near 1700 cm–1 as a weak but sharp peak, the latter can be observed near 1383 cm–1 as an intense and sharp peak. This phenomenon is in line with expectations for the ligand carboxyl. The several weak peaks from wavenumber of 960 to 1300 cm–1 cannot be precisely determined and might be due to the C–C single bond stretching vibration and molecular skeletal vibration. The sharp and intense band in the range of 846 to 927 cm–1 is due to the asymmetric stretching modes of the uranyl cation, while the symmetric stretching modes are observed in the range of 757 to 809 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy (IR)

Complexes 1 and 3 were characterized by IR spectroscopy (Figure S2), and their IR spectra are similar. Hence, we only identify the IR spectroscopy of compound 1 in detail. The broad peak appearing near 3440 cm-1 is due to the stretching vibration of O-H bond in dissociative water. The aromatic ring C-H stretching vibration absorptions and out of plane bending absorptions are observed in the range of 2800 to 3100 cm-1 and 665 to 750 cm-1, respectively. Another characteristic absorption spectroscopy of the aromatic ring is the skeletal vibrations that can be observed near 1591, 1530, and 1430 cm-1. For the carboxylate groups, the most important absorption peaks are attributed to CO and C-O stretching vibration absorption, and the former appears near 1700 cm-1 as a weak but sharp peak, the latter can be observed near 1383 cm-1 as an intense and sharp peak. This phenomenon is in line with expectations for the ligand carboxyl. The several weak peaks from wavenumber of 960 to 1300 cm-1 cannot be precisely determined and might be due to the C-C single bond stretching vibration and molecular skeletal vibration. The sharp and intense band in the range of 846 to 927 cm-1 is due to the asymmetric stretching modes of the uranyl cation, while the symmetric stretching modes are observed in the range of 757 to 809 cm-1.

elements.content: The compounds 1 and 3 are stable in air and insoluble in water. To examine the thermal stability of compounds 1 and 3, TG analyses were then carried out, the results are provided in Figure S3. The experiments were performed in the air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C·min–1. The TG curve of compound 1 exhibits two three-separated weight loss stages. The solid sample reduces 2.5% weight from 150 to 300 °C due to the loss of water molecules. The second weight loss stage occurs from 300 to 360 °C with weight reduction of 21.6%, which corresponds to the loss of phen ligands. With the further increase of temperature, the structure becomes unstable and starts to decompose. When the temperature is in excess of 465 °C, the TG curve exhibits nearly a platform, the remaining 31.9% product corresponding to the U3O8. The TG curve of compound 3 exhibits three weight loss stages, which are not separated very well. The solid sample reduces about 10% weight from 200 to 320 °C due to the loss of disordered solvent molecules. With the temperature increase to 340 °C, the second weight loss stage finishes with mass decrement about 2%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules of Na+ cation. The following weight loss stage until 490 °C reveals completely decomposed of major structure, and the remaining product is attributed to U3O8 and Na2O.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

The compounds 1 and 3 are stable in air and insoluble in water. To examine the thermal stability of compounds 1 and 3, TG analyses were then carried out, the results are provided in Figure S3. The experiments were performed in the air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C⋅min-1. The TG curve of compound 1 exhibits two three-separated weight loss stages. The solid sample reduces 2.5% weight from 150 to 300 °C due to the loss of water molecules. The second weight loss stage occurs from 300 to 360 °C with weight reduction of 21.6%, which corresponds to the loss of phen ligands. With the further increase of temperature, the structure becomes unstable and starts to decompose. When the temperature is in excess of 465 °C, the TG curve exhibits nearly a platform, the remaining 31.9% product corresponding to the U3O8. The TG curve of compound 3 exhibits three weight loss stages, which are not separated very well. The solid sample reduces about 10% weight from 200 to 320 °C due to the loss of disordered solvent molecules. With the temperature increase to 340 °C, the second weight loss stage finishes with mass decrement about 2%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules of Na+ cation. The following weight loss stage until 490 °C reveals completely decomposed of major structure, and the remaining product is attributed to U3O8 and Na2O.

elements.content: In order to confirm the phase purity of compounds 1 and 3, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were also recorded. It is found that the main diffraction peaks of compounds 1 and 3 are comparable to the corresponding simulated results from the single-crystal diffraction (Figure S4 and S5).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

In order to confirm the phase purity of compounds 1 and 3, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were also recorded. It is found that the main diffraction peaks of compounds 1 and 3 are comparable to the corresponding simulated results from the single-crystal diffraction (Figure S4 and S5).

elements.content: The compounds 1 and 3 were tested, and no characteristic emission of uranyl cations was observed. In fact, not all uranyl compounds can exhibit luminescence of uranyl cations. These phenomena are relevant to several factors such as the distinct coordination environment around the UO2 2+ moiety, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, size and quality of the crystal, etc.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

The compounds 1 and 3 were tested, and no characteristic emission of uranyl cations was observed. In fact, not all uranyl compounds can exhibit luminescence of uranyl cations. These phenomena are relevant to several factors such as the distinct coordination environment around the UO2 2+ moiety, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, size and quality of the crystal, etc.

elements.content: In conclusion, four new coordination polymers with aromatic heterocycle carboxylate (H2bqdc) and rigid (phen), semiflexible (bpy), flexible (bpp) auxiliary ligands were constructed and characterized. The topological structures feature the 1D chain to the 3D framework. Moreover, both compounds 2 and 3 are UOFs with cavity size of 12.28(2) Å × 7.16(3) Å and 10.07(0) Å × 13.86(2) Å, respectively. This work shows that the N-donor ancillary ligands play critical roles in the construction of uranyl CPs. The steric effect of phen ligand leads to the serious deviation of coordination atoms from the equatorial plane of uranyl cation and forces the coordination hexagonal flat to warp to the quite rare chair-type structure. At the same time, the phen ligand acts as terminator to prevent the 1D wave-shaped chain of compound 1 from linking together to generate a structure with higher dimensionality. Although the bpy ligand does not coordinate with uranyl cation in compound 2, it is involved in the building of the 2D layer structure via hydrogen bond. Compounds 3 and 4 were obtained from the same reaction system. In the former compound, bpp ligand acts as a template agent. However, the bpp ligand participates in the coordination with metal ion, the formation of hydrogen bond, and π···π interaction in the latter compound. This work presents almost all the functions of the N-donor ancillary ligands in the construction of uranyl CPs: acting as organic base to adjust pH, coordinating to the metal center, involving in the formation of the intermolecular weak interaction, keeping the charge balance after protonation, acting as guest molecule to fill in the void space of the UOF, and acting as template agent. Introducing the organic base ancillary ligands into the reaction system is an effective way to synthesize novel uranyl compounds. In addition, according to the DFT calculations, obvious metal–ligand bonding orbitals have been found in the MOs of the uranyl compounds 1–3, which are mainly attributed to U 5f, 6d, 7s and O, N 2p orbital interactions. Besides, there is no uranium–uranium bonding interaction in compound 2.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, four new coordination polymers with aromatic heterocycle carboxylate (H2bqdc) and rigid (phen), semiflexible (bpy), flexible (bpp) auxiliary ligands were constructed and characterized. The topological structures feature the 1D chain to the 3D framework. Moreover, both compounds 2 and 3 are UOFs with cavity size of 12.28(2) Å × 7.16(3) Å and 10.07(0) Å × 13.86(2) Å, respectively. This work shows that the N-donor ancillary ligands play critical roles in the construction of uranyl CPs. The steric effect of phen ligand leads to the serious deviation of coordination atoms from the equatorial plane of uranyl cation and forces the coordination hexagonal flat to warp to the quite rare chair-type structure. At the same time, the phen ligand acts as terminator to prevent the 1D wave-shaped chain of compound 1 from linking together to generate a structure with higher dimensionality. Although the bpy ligand does not coordinate with uranyl cation in compound 2, it is involved in the building of the 2D layer structure via hydrogen bond. Compounds 3 and 4 were obtained from the same reaction system. In the former compound, bpp ligand acts as a template agent. However, the bpp ligand participates in the coordination with metal ion, the formation of hydrogen bond, and π⋅⋅⋅π interaction in the latter compound. This work presents almost all the functions of the N-donor ancillary ligands in the construction of uranyl CPs: acting as organic base to adjust pH, coordinating to the metal center, involving in the formation of the intermolecular weak interaction, keeping the charge balance after protonation, acting as guest molecule to fill in the void space of the UOF, and acting as template agent. Introducing the organic base ancillary ligands into the reaction system is an effective way to synthesize novel uranyl compounds. In addition, according to the DFT calculations, obvious metal-ligand bonding orbitals have been found in the MOs of the uranyl compounds 1-3, which are mainly attributed to U 5f, 6d, 7s and O, N 2p orbital interactions. Besides, there is no uranium-uranium bonding interaction in compound 2.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2bqdc (51.64 mg, 0.15 mmol), phen (28.03 mg, 0.15 mmol), NaOH (4.08 mg, 0.1 mmol), and ultrapure water (5.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, then cooled to room temperature naturally. Yellow crystals of compound 1 were produced, then filtered off, washed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air-drying at room temperature. Yield: 41.6 mg (51.3% based on uranium). In the absence of the auxiliary ligands (phen), only the brown block noncrystalline materials were observed.

Na­[(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(bqdc)<sub>3</sub>Na­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>) and Na­(bqdc)<sub>0.5</sub>(bpp)­(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>4</bold>)

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 0.20 mL), H2bqdc (51.57 mg, 0.15 mmol), bpp (27.01 mg, 0.15 mmol), NaOH (4.06 mg, 0.1 mmol), ultrapure water (5.0 mL) was loaded into a 15 mL autoclave. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 180 °C in an oven for 3 days, then cooled to room temperature naturally. Dark yellow crystals of compound 3 were produced, then filtered off, washed with ultrapure water and ethanol, and subjected to air-drying at room temperature. Yield: 34.5 mg (40.9% based on uranium). Here, the auxiliary ligand was not incorporated into the structure of compound 3. Surprisingly, few light yellow block-shaped crystals of compound 4 were observed in one pot.

Modulating the topological structures of uranyl compounds of bqdc2− ligand by altering N-donor ancillary ligands: from 1D chain to 3D framework. Compounds 2 and 3 are UOFs with the cavity size of 12.28(2) Å × 7.16(3) Å and 10.07(0) Å × 13.86(2) Å, respectively.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

The compounds 1 and 3 are stable in air and insoluble in water. To examine the thermal stability of compounds 1 and 3, TG analyses were then carried out, the results are provided in Figure S3. The experiments were performed in the air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C·min–1. The TG curve of compound 1 exhibits two three-separated weight loss stages. The solid sample reduces 2.5% weight from 150 to 300 °C due to the loss of water molecules. The second weight loss stage occurs from 300 to 360 °C with weight reduction of 21.6%, which corresponds to the loss of phen ligands. With the further increase of temperature, the structure becomes unstable and starts to decompose. When the temperature is in excess of 465 °C, the TG curve exhibits nearly a platform, the remaining 31.9% product corresponding to the U3O8. The TG curve of compound 3 exhibits three weight loss stages, which are not separated very well. The solid sample reduces about 10% weight from 200 to 320 °C due to the loss of disordered solvent molecules. With the temperature increase to 340 °C, the second weight loss stage finishes with mass decrement about 2%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules of Na+ cation. The following weight loss stage until 490 °C reveals completely decomposed of major structure, and the remaining product is attributed to U3O8 and Na2O.

The solid sample reduces about 10% weight from 200 to 320 °C due to the loss of disordered solvent molecules. With the temperature increase to 340 °C, the second weight loss stage finishes with mass decrement about 2%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules of Na+ cation. The following weight loss stage until 490 °C reveals completely decomposed of major structure, and the remaining product is attributed to U3O8 and Na2O.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of two coordination water molecules of Na+ cation
